questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with a sore throat, fever, tonsillar exudates, and cervical lymphadenopathy for 3 days. She has a history of frequent sore throats requiring prolonged antibiotics, easy bruising, and bruises of different ages on her arms.  She is fair-skinned and has blonde hair.  Her birth and family history are unremarkable. What is the likely defect?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of Chediak Higashi syndrome which is a disorder of phagocytosis.

It is an autosomal recessive disorder that causes a loss-of-function mutation of the LYST gene encoding for the lysosomal trafficking regulator—a protein required for the normal packaging and distribution of granules. This defect results in defective chemotaxis, phagolysosome fusion, degranulation of T-cells and NK cells, and ADP granule function in platelets. 

Patients with Chediak-Higashi syndrome may present clinically with persistent skin, respiratory, and gastrointestinal infections, particularly due to Staphylococcus aureus. They may also exhibit partial oculo-cutaneous albinism, and platelet dysfunction leading to increased bleeding time, easy bruising, and excessive bleeding despite normal platelet counts. Neurological dysfunctions such as progressive peripheral neuropathy, nystagmus, and mental retardation are common, and patients may experience an accelerated phase with lymphoma-like illness and hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis. The latter is a life-threatening condition characterized by prolonged high fever, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and cytopenia, and it carries a very poor prognosis.

Diagnosis can be done by detecting the presence of peroxidase-positive giant primary granules in neutrophils and other granule-bearing cells on Wright’s stain. Genetic detection may be confirmatory. 

The image below shows a neutrophil in Chediak Higashi Syndrome showing polymorphonuclear leukocytes with abundant giant intracytoplasmic granules-

Other options:

Option A: Disorders of T cells include conditions such as Severe Combined Immunodeficiency Disorder, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome and DiGeorge syndrome

Option B: Disorders of B cells include conditions such as hyper IgM syndrome and IgA deficiency. 

Option C: Disorders of the complement system include angioedema.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: Which of the following mucopolysaccharidosis does not show leukocyte inclusions?
questions.solution:
Morquio disease does not show leukocyte inclusions.

Morquio disease is different from other mucopolysaccharidoses as it presents as spondyloepiphyseal skeletal dysplasia. 

 

Manifestations in Mucopolysaccharidoses

I-H: Hurler disease

I-S: Scheie disease

II: Hunter disease

III: Sanfilippo disease

IV: Morquio disease

VI: Maroteaux-Lamy disease

VII: Sly disease.

Mucopolysaccharidoses are a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans.

  • Most common MPS: Sanfilippo > Hurler’s and Hunter’s
  • MPS with no mental retardation: Scheie’s disease, Morquio syndrome, and Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome.
  • MPS with no corneal clouding: Hunter’s disease and Sanfilippo syndrome
  • MPS with XLR inheritance: Hunter’s disease
  • MPS with no visceromegaly: Morquio’s disease
  • Skeletal deformity associated with all MPS: Dysostosis multiplex
  • MPS with no leucocyte inclusions: Morquio’s disease

 Type

 Enzyme involved

Chromosome 

 Morquio syndrome A

  Galactosamine 6-sulfatase Chromosome 16

 Morquio syndrome B

 β-Galactosidase

Chromosome  4

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman presents with acute onset abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has a low-grade fever, with a pulse rate of 90 bpm and blood pressure of 126/84 mm Hg. She has regular menstrual cycles of 28 days. Pelvic examination shows a tender right adnexal mass. Ultrasound scan reveals a swollen oedematous ovary, globular in shape with disruption in adnexal flow seen on doppler. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Urine pregnancy testing- negative
Serum β-HCG level- 1 mIU/L
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of ovarian torsion.

Torsion of the ovaries is a gynecological emergency and is most commonly seen in women of the reproductive age group. Ovarian cysts including mucous cystadenomas and dermoid cysts have the highest risks of undergoing torsion. Adnexal masses measuring >6 cm in diameter have the highest rates of torsion.

A patient with torsion presents with sharp lower abdominal pain, usually localized to the involved side with radiation to the flank, groin, or thigh. Nausea and vomiting are commonly associated. Adnexal necrosis may cause a low-grade fever. 

During torsion, the low-pressure veins are initially compressed by the twisting pedicle. This leads to continuous inflow with decreased outflow causing stromal edema and congestion. The increasing stromal swelling later compresses the arteries causing ischemia and necrosis.

On USG, the ovary appears enlarged, globular, and has a heterogenous appearance compared to the contralateral ovary due to edema, engorgement, and hemorrhage. Twisting of the vascular pedicle may give rise to a 'whirlpool sign', a round hyperechoic structure with concentric hypoechoic stripes. Colour Doppler sonography should be performed in suspected torsion as it may show disruption to blood flow, which is highly suggestive of torsion. However, some cases of incomplete torsion or chronic torsion, may not show decreased flow on Doppler. MRI or CT imaging can be used in patients with normal Doppler but with characteristic signs and symptoms of torsion, to confirm or rule out the diagnosis.

Management involves urgent laparotomy or laparoscopic evaluation. Salvage of the involved adnexa with the removal of any associated cyst/tumor and possible oophoropexy are the goals. However, necrosis of the adnexa necessitates the removal of the adnexal structures.

Other options:

Option A: In a woman of reproductive age group, ovulatory pain following the rupture of Graafian follicle (ovulation) may present similarly with lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. This patient has a regular 28-day cycle and should have ovulated around the 14th day. 

Option B: Tubo-ovarian abscess presents with a more indolent course, and may be associated with fever. The characteristic appearance on USG is of a complex, multilocular mass. 

Option C: Ectopic pregnancy presents with nausea, vomiting, and adnexal pain, with or without a mass. However, this patient has a negative UPT, and serum β-HCG level is in the non-pregnant range (< 2 mIU/L) excluding ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy with sickle-cell anemia was brought by his parents with complaints of fever and a runny nose. The child has a maculopapular rash with a lacy pattern on his trunk and extremities, sparing the palm and soles. He also has a rash on his face as shown below. What specific complication would you anticipate in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical symptoms and the typical ‘slapped cheek appearance’ that is the erythematous facial flushing as shown in the image are suggestive of erythema infectiosum. A transient aplastic crisis is a complication that is anticipated in this patient. 

Erythema infectiosum or fifth disease is a viral infection caused by parvovirus B19. It usually has three phases:

  • First phase - sudden onset diffuse and macular, asymptomatic erythema of the cheeks or slapped cheek appearance. Prodromal symptoms may occur
  • Second phase - begins after 1–4 days, with discrete erythematous macules and papules on the proximal extremities and later the trunk
  • Third phase - recurring stage, the eruption is greatly reduced or invisible, only to recur after the patient is exposed to heat or sunlight, or in response to crying or exercise

Parvovirus B-19-induced transient aplastic crisis is a complication seen in patients with all types of chronic hemolytic anemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and pyruvate kinase deficiency.

Other options:

Option A: Coronary aneurysm is a complication of Kawasaki disease. Patients with this disease present with high fever for at least 5 days along with at least four out of the five characteristic features: polymorphous exanthem, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis with limbal sparing, lip cracking, and oral mucosal erythema with strawberry tongue appearance, cervical lymphadenopathy, and extremity involvement - erythema of palms and soles with edema of hands and legs.

The image given below shows strawberry tongue and erythema of hands seen in Kawasaki disease.

Option B: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a complication of measles. The characteristic presentation of measles includes a high fever, cough, coryza, and a maculopapular rash which typically begins after 3-5 days of fever in a cephalocaudal fashion involving the palms and soles. A pathognomonic feature of measles is the Koplik spots which are bluish-white spots located on the buccal mucosa opposite the 1st and 2nd molars.

The image given below shows rashes and Koplik spots of measles.

Option D: Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis seen as a complication of group A streptococcal infection (more commonly seen with skin strains and a few pharyngeal strains). Common streptococcal infections in childhood are bacterial pharyngitis, Scarlett fever, non-bullous impetigo, and erysipelas. They present with acute pharyngitis or erythematous papulovesicular lesions which can become purulent.

The image given below shows the rash and strawberry tongue appearance of Scarlett fever.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the imaging of Meckel’s diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Technitium (Tc) 99m Pertechnetate is used for the imaging of Meckel's diverticulum.

Uses of Tc-99m pertechnetate include -

  • Thyroid imaging for thyroid nodules and ectopic thyroid
  • Salivary gland imaging
  • Meckel scan
  • Gastric emptying studies, intestinal and rectal functional studies.
  • Vesicoureteral reflux imaging.

Related Pearl: Radionuclide agents and their uses

Monoclonal antibody for colorectal cancer

questions.text: The image below shows the histology of a normal lymph node. Which of the following sites marked in the image, allows affinity maturation of B lymphocytes?
questions.solution:
B-Lymphocytes undergo affinity maturation in the germinal center (marked as 3) of lymph nodes and produce antibodies.

The structures marked in the above histological section of the lymph node are as follows:

1 - Capsule;

2 - Subcapsular sinus;

3 - Germinal center;

4 - Lymphoid nodule;

5 - Trabeculae 

Histology of lymph node:

Lymph nodes are surrounded by a capsule with a subcapsular sinus below the capsule. Each lymph node consists of a connective tissue framework and numerous lymphocytes of all types which are arranged in a stroma of reticulin fibers and cells to form 3 major regions within each Lymph node:

  • Cortex - It contains subcapsular sinuses, lymphoid nodules, and densely packed lymphocytes. It stains darkly. Each nodule has a paler staining germinal center surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. It contains B lymphocytes and follicular dendritic cells.
  • Paracortex (deeper cortex) - It lacks nodules and has fewer lymphocytes. It is, therefore, lighter homogenously staining. It contains T-lymphocytes and interdigitating dendritic cells.
  • Medulla -  with prominent draining sinusoids adjacent to the hilum. It has less densely packed lymphocytes arranged in medullary cords and macrophages.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient with traumatic perforation of the tympanic membrane is scheduled to undergo a tympanic membrane grafting. Which of the following inhalational agents would you avoid in this patient?
questions.solution:
The inhalational agent to be avoided in a patient undergoing tympanic membrane grafting is nitrous oxide.

Nitrous oxide has the potential to expand air containing cavities as it can diffuse into and accumulate in them. Hence, it should be avoided in patients undergoing tympanic membrane grafting.

Other conditions in which nitrous oxide might be hazardous include:

  • venous or arterial air embolism
  • pneumothorax
  • acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distention
  • intracranial air (pneumocephalus following dural closure or pneumoencephalography)
  • pulmonary air cysts
  • intraocular air bubbles

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman alleges that a man assaulted her the previous night, causing a wound over her forearm. According to her history, the wound should be about 12–14 hours old. If the history regarding the timing of the injury is accurate, you would expect the abrasion to appear as

choices.text: A fresh bright red lesion without any scab
A scab that is about to fall off

questions.solution:
An abrasion that was sustained 12 to 14 hours ago would show a bright red scab as lymph and blood dry up.

Abrasions are superficial wounds produced due to the destruction of the epidermis. Although the exact age of the wound cannot be determined, based on the healing and appearance of the wound, an estimated time can be given.

Abrasion types:

  • Linear abrasions (scratches): Caused by relative movement of a pointed object on the skin. It leaves a clean area at the start and tags at the end.
    • e.g. nail, thorn, or the point of a sword or knife.
  • Grazed abrasions (sliding /scrapping/grinding abrasion): Caused by relative movement of a rough surface on a wide area of skin.
    • known as brush burns.
    • e.g. fall, a victim being dragged on the ground, road traffic accidents.
  • Impact abrasions (imprint abrasions): Caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin, without any movement
    • e.g. fingernails, tires, grills, bicycle chains, or bite marks.
  • Friction abrasions (pressure abrasion): Caused by pressure upon the skin with an agent with a smooth surface, accompanied by movement.
    • e.g. ligature marks around the neck in hanging, strangulation.
  • Patterned abrasion: Caused by impact abrasion or pressure abrasion, reproducing the pattern of the object causing it

Note: Grazed abrasion is the most common type of abrasion.

Related Pearl: Age of bruise and abrasion

Age and color change of bruise/contusion:

 

Colour Due to Duration  
Red Haemoglobin (fresh blood) Fresh  
Blue Deoxygenated haemoglobin Few hours to 3 days 
Bluish black/ brown Hemosiderin 4th day  
Green Hematoidin 5 to 6 days 
Yellow Bilirubin 7 to 12 days 
Normal colour Pigment removed by phagocytes  2 weeks

 

The image given below shows the age and colour change of bruise:

 

Age of abrasion:

Colour of scab Duration
Bright red 12-24 hrs
Reddish brown 2-3 days
Dark brown to brownish black 4-7 days
Scab dries shrinks and falls off After 7 days

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes for an evaluation of blood pressure. He had a history of occasional flank pain and a family history of stroke in his father. His BP is 160/90 mm of Hg in both arms. Further evaluation with CT was done and shown below. Which of the following is the most common extrarenal manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation of hypertension, family history of stroke, along with the CT findings showing bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts and liver cysts suggests a diagnosis of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). The most common extrarenal manifestation seen in ADPKD is hepatic cysts.

ADPKD is caused by mutations in PKD1 and PKD2 which code for polycystin 1 and 2 respectively. They present incidentally with hypertension, abdominal mass or flank pain. Hematuria can also be present 

The most common extrarenal manifestation is hepatic cysts which are derived from the biliary epithelium. Other extra-renal manifestations of ADPKD:

  • Pancreatic cysts
  • Berry aneurysms
  • Colonic diverticula
  • Abdominal hernias
  • Mitral valve prolapse 

Management comprises of blood pressure control, antibiotics like trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, quinolones and chloramphenicol for 4-6 weeks, and analgesics. Surgical decompression for cysts may be done. 

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: Among the following women with bleeding per vaginum (PV) who are being evaluated, which would be diagnosed as secondary post-partum hemorrhage?

choices.text: A 32 year old woman at 40 weeks gestation in second stage of labour
A 26 year old woman who delivered twins vaginally 6 hours ago
A 29 year old woman who delivered a preterm baby 1 week ago
A 36 year old woman at 32 weeks gestation bleeding PV

questions.solution:
A 29-year-old woman who delivered a preterm baby 1 week ago, now having bleeding per vaginum has secondary post-partum hemorrhage (PPH).

Secondary postpartum hemorrhage is defined as bleeding from or into the genital tract, occurring beyond 24 hours of birth and within the puerperium. 

Causes of secondary PPH include: 

  • Retained bits of placental cotyledons or membranes
  • Infection of deep cervicovaginal laceration and separation of the slough
  • Endometritis and subinvolution of the site of the placenta 
  • Withdrawal bleeding following estrogen therapy for lactation suppression
  • Rare causes - chorionepithelioma, puerperal inversion of the uterus

Other Options:

Options A and D: These women have antepartum hemorrhage. Antepartum hemorrhage is defined as bleeding from or into the genital tract after the 28th week of pregnancy but before the birth of the baby. Therefore a patient in the second stage of labour and a patient with bleeding PV at 32 weeks gestation have antepartum hemorrhage.

Option B: This woman has primary PPH. Bleeding within 24 hours following the birth of the baby. Common causes of primary PPH include atony of the uterus, trauma during labor, retained tissues, and coagulopathies. Primary PPH is of two types:

  • Third stage hemorrhage - bleeding before the expulsion of placenta
  • True post-partum hemorrhage -bleeding after the expulsion of placenta

questions.text: An MRI of a female patient with new-onset seizures revealed a large, ring-enhancing mass with central necrosis and surrounding edema, crossing the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes. Subsequently, she underwent surgical resection of the mass. Grossly, it was a grayish-white solid tumor with yellowish areas of necrosis, with interspersed areas of hemorrhages. Microscopy findings are shown below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with MRI findings is strongly suggestive of glioblastoma or grade IV astrocytoma.

It affects people usually in the sixth or seventh decade. These tumors may arise de novo or may result from a malignant transformation of lower-grade astrocytomas. Mutations of isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH), PTEN, and epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene are implicated in the pathogenesis.

They preferentially spread along the condensed white matter tracts such as corticospinal tracts and corpus callosum and can give rise to the butterfly glioma, involving the contralateral hemisphere. 

Clinically, patients present with headaches, seizures due to raised intracranial pressure, or focal neurologic deficits, depending upon the site involved. 

Grossly, glioblastomas are found to infiltrate the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. They have grayish tumor cells with central yellowish necrosis and multiple areas of hemorrhages. Microscopically, they are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity. Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic. They exhibit pseudopalisading—dense arrangement of tumor cells lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis.

Radiologically, glioblastomas appear as a large ring-enhancing heterogeneous mass with central necrosis and surrounding edema that crosses the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes. The surrounding edema may be interspersed with infiltrating tumor cells. The tumor may show partial or complete enhancement on contrast study. 

Standard treatment includes surgery followed by a combination of radiotherapy and chemotherapy with temozolomide following surgical resection. Bevacizumab, which is a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) antibody, may be used in the treatment of recurrent glioblastoma. 

Option B: Craniopharyngioma - These are slow-growing, hypothalamic suprasellar tumors arising from vestigial remnants of the Rathke pouch. They often encroach on the optic chiasm or cranial nerves, and not infrequently they bulge into the floor of the third ventricle and base of the brain.

Two distinct histologic variants are recognized are adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma (most common in children) and papillary craniopharyngioma (most common in adults).

Option C: Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors of adults that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid and are usually attached to the dura. They are found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus. The most common histological pattern seen is meningothelial pattern, where clusters of epithelioid cells with indiscernible cell membranes are present.

The image below shows meningothelial or syncytial pattern:

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presents with a 5x4x3cm lump in the right breast. It is hard in consistency and is fixed to the skin. On examination, there are fixed and matted axillary lymph nodes in the left and right axilla. Mammography reveals the presence of microcalcifications with irregular spiculated margins. A tru-cut biopsy is performed which shows ductal carcinoma. What is the staging of the tumor as per the recent AJCC classification?
questions.solution:
A contralateral lymph node involvement is considered metastasis. The presence of metastasis classifies the tumor under stage IV.

The TNM status in the above scenario is:

  • Tumor: Skin involvement over the breast- peau d'orange appearance classifies this as stage T4b.
  • Nodes: Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes come under N2A.
  • Metastasis: Contralateral lymph node involvement (Here, mass is on the right breast and axillary lymph nodes on the left side are involved) is considered as M1.

Some important considerations while staging a breast tumor:

  • In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is considered. For example, if a mass is 6*2cm in size, 6cm is taken into account and it comes under T3 (>5cm).
  • Any skin involvement other than those mentioned under T4b and T4d is not considered for staging. Thus, skin changes like dimpling of skin or nipple retraction are not considered for staging.
  • Supraclavicular lymph node involvement indicates N3c.
  • Metastasis to any contralateral lymph node or metastasis to any lymph node other than those mentioned in N staging is considered distant metastasis (M1). Thus, the involvement of the cervical lymph node (ipsilateral or contralateral) would be considered a distant metastasis.
  • If two masses are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger mass.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of Carcinoma Breast

Tumor (T)

Description
Tx

Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0

No evidence of primary tumor
Tis (DCIS) Ductal carcinoma in situ
Tis (Paget) Paget disease not associated with invasive carcinoma or DCIS
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1mic ≤ 0.1 cm

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – Inflammatory breast carcinoma (typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
M0 Metastasis absent
M1 Metastasis present

 

Stages T, N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

 M0
Stage IV

Any T, Any N

 M1

# Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of the chest wall.

* Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage 4d) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of the breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text: A patient is undergoing an evaluation for shortness of breath. A test to assess the diffusing capacity of the lungs is done. This is measured using one of the following gas components?
questions.solution:
The diffusion capacity of the lungs is measured with carbon monoxide (CO).

The diffusing of CO is diffusion-limited and hence the diffusion capacity for CO called DLCO is measured as an index of diffusing capacity of the lung.

The diffusing capacity of the lung for a given gas is directly proportional to the surface area of the alveolar-capillary membrane and inversely proportional to its thickness.

In this test, a small amount of CO is used to measure the alveolar gas exchange during a 10-second breath-hold. The CO in exhaled breath is then analyzed and the quantity of CO that crosses the alveolar membrane is determined. The normal value of DLco at rest is about 25 mL/min/mm Hg.

DLCO is decreased in patients with:

  • Interstitial lung disease
  • Emphysema (chronic bronchitis usually have normal DLCO)

DLCO is increased in patients with:

  • Obesity
  • Asthma
  • Pulmonary hemorrhage
  • Exercise

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents with a right-sided headache for 2 weeks along with jaw pain. It has progressively increased in severity. Of late, she also has a loss of appetite, malaise, and fatigue. She also has a history of stiffness and pain in her shoulders and hip, which has disabled her from doing household chores. On examination, the patient appears pale and the temperature is 99.8F. Gentle pressure on the scalp elicits focal tenderness.  ESR is elevated. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical scenario is suggestive of giant cell arteritis with polymyalgia rheumatica. The patient should be immediately started on steroids. 

Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and in people aged >50 years.

The clinical features include headache associated with scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Half of the patients have signs of superficial temporal artery inflammation, including erythema, pain on palpation, nodularity, thickening, or reduced pulsation on the affected side. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. It is very commonly associated with polymyalgia rheumatica characterized by morning stiffness and pain around the shoulders and hip. 

A dreaded complication is ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to sudden blindness. Therefore, patients with a clinical diagnosis of GCA, especially with headaches or visual symptoms should immediately be started on steroids. Else damage may be irreversible if treatment is delayed beyond 48 hours.

The diagnosis can be confirmed by temporal artery biopsy. It may not be positive in all patients, due to patchy involvement of the vessels. Obtaining a biopsy segment of 3-5 cm with serial sectioning may yield a positive result. A color doppler ultrasound can be used as an alternative to temporal artery biopsy. 

Newer drugs used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis are tocilizumab (anti-IL-6 receptor) and abatacept (CTLA4-Ig).

Other options:

Option A: Sumatriptan is used in the treatment of migraine headaches. Although migraine headaches commonly present with unilateral headache, the other clinical features in this patient are suggestive of GCA.

Option B: There is a limited role of vascular imaging in the diagnosis of GCA. Additionally, the patient must be started on steroids without awaiting diagnostic confirmation when GCA is suspected.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy is admitted to the hospital with a three-day history of gasping and choking spells. They are associated with repeated coughing bouts which are occasionally followed by episodes of vomiting. His mother says that he has been unwell for about two weeks now. On examination, the baby was found to have an increased breathing rate, which was labored. Blood work showed an abnormally large percentage of lymphocytes (70%). Nasopharyngeal swabs cultured on a selective medium yielded grayish, "mercury-like" colonies and a gram stain revealed minute gram-negative coccobacilli. Which of the following is false about the diagnosis/etiological agent?

choices.text: The causative organism is fastidious and requires an enriched medium for growth
It requires X and V factor for growth
An effective vaccine is available to prevent the illness
The factor responsible for the profound lymphocytosis is an A/B structured toxin.

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture strongly points towards a diagnosis of pertussis/whooping cough caused by Bordetella pertussis. It does not require X and V factor for growth. 

X and V factors are required for the growth of Hemophilus species. 

Bordetella pertussis is a gram-negative coccobacillus. It does not grow on simple media such as nutrient agar and requires enriched selective media such as Bordet-Gengou medium and Regan Lowe medium. On the Bordet-Gengou medium, the colonies resemble 'mercury droplets' as described in this clinical picture. 

It produces various virulence factors and toxins that are responsible for the clinical disease. They include-

  • Pertussis toxin- It is a classic A/B structure toxin with subunit A that carries the biologic activity and a subunit B that binds the complex to the cell membrane. The A-subunit ADP-ribosylates the inhibitory G-protein (Gi). It causes lymphocytosis, sensitization to histamine, and enhanced insulin secretion.
  • Filamentous hemagglutinin- Promotes adherence of the B.pertussis to the cilia. It also has a hemagglutinin activity. 
  • Adenylate cyclase toxin- Inhibits phagocytic cell oxidative responses and natural killer cell (NK cell) activity.
  • Tracheal toxin- Causes destruction of the ciliated cells in the trachea. 
  • Other virulence factors- Includes Pertactin, heat-labile toxin, lipopolysaccharide.

Clinically, the disease is transmitted via respiratory droplets. It courses over 3 phases after an incubation period of 2 weeks-

  • Catarrhal - lasts for 1-2 weeks and consists of cough, coryza, and nasopharyngeal secretions.
  • Paroxysmal - lasts for 2-6 weeks and consists of worsening paroxysms of productive whooping cough. Whooping cough derives its name from the inspiratory whoop at the end of a coughing bout. It becomes more frequent and ends with vomiting. 
  • Convalescent - Intensity and frequency of cough decrease over 4 weeks.

The diagnosis is made on clinical grounds. A specific diagnosis can be done by isolation of the organism from a nasopharyngeal swab or nasopharyngeal aspiration, and cultured on Bordet-Gengou medium.

Management involves antibiotic therapy and supportive care. Pertussis can be prevented through vaccination. Every infant should receive three injections of the pertussis vaccine during the first year of life followed by booster series for a total of five doses. Acellular vaccines contain a few of the following antigens: inactivated pertussis toxin, filamentous hemagglutinin, fimbrial proteins, and pertactin.

 

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

Appropriate culture media for various bacteria:

Organism Medium for culture
Staph aureus Mannitol salt agar
ludlam’s medium
salt milk agar
Strep. Pyogenes Crystal violet blood agar
Neisseria meningitidis Thayer martin medium
Corynebacterium Potassium tellurite agar
Tinsdale medium
Mcleod medium
B.anthrax PLET medium
B.cereus MYPA (Mannitol egg yolk phenol red polymyxin agar)
PEMBA(polymyxin in egg yolk mannitol bromothymol blue agar
Clostridium  CCFA ( cefoxitin cycloserine fructose agar)
Shigella DCA, XLD, SSA
Salmonella Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium
Vibrio TCBS
Monsur GTTA
Pseudomonas Cetrimide agar
B.pseudomallei Ashdown medium
H. influenza Fildes agar
Levinthal medium
Bordetella Bordet-Gengou glycerine potato blood agar
Brucella Casteneda medium
B.burgdorferi BSK medium
Campylobacter

Skirrow's, Butzler's and Campy BAP media
Legionella pneumophilia

BCYE medium
Leptospira EMJH medium

questions.text: A 20-year-old gymnast came to the emergency department with a history of a fall an hour ago. He was practicing his vault when he fell on his head. He complains of pain over his nose and a bloody discharge from his nose. A tissue paper he used to blow his nose into, shows bloodstains with charectaristic appearance as shown below.  Which of the following laboratory tests would be the best to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
History of head trauma along with nasal discharge that shows double target sign on a handkerchief/tissue paper is consistent with traumatic CSF rhinorrhea. The single best lab investigation to establish the diagnosis of CSF rhinorrhea is the assay of beta-2 transferrin.

It is absent in normal nasal discharge and is present only in the CSF, perilymph, and aqueous humor. Detection of beta-2-transferrin is done by electrophoresis and is a very sensitive and specific test for CSF leak. 

Although the beta-2-transferrin assay may confirm the diagnosis of CSF rhinorrhea, a high-resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) is required to localize the site of the defect causing the CSF leak. 

An intrathecal fluorescein study may be performed preoperatively or intraoperatively to confirm the site of the defect. 

Treatment of CSF rhinorrhea:

  • Early cases of post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhea are managed conservatively by placing the patient in the semi-sitting position
  • Avoiding blowing of nose, sneezing, and straining.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics to prevent meningitis.
  • Persistent cases may be treated surgically by intracranial or nasal endoscopic approach.
  • Nasal endoscopic approach is useful for leaks from the frontal sinus, cribriform plate, ethmoid or sphenoid sinuses.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with complaints of blurring of vision and progressive discomfort in both his eyes for the past 1 week. There is an antecedent history of penetrating trauma to his right eye 6 weeks back. Slit lamp examination reveals mutton-fat keratic precipitates in the anterior chamber. Direct ophthalmoscopy shows discrete yellow-white nodules in the fundus. What is the main modality of initial management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmitis. Pulse intravenous methylprednisolone therapy is the main modality of the initial management of this condition.

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous pan-uveitis that usually occurs after penetrative trauma. It can also develop after intraocular surgery. Both the injured eye (exciting eye) and fellow eye (sympathizing eye) develop panuveitis. Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk.

It is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. According to the allergic theory, the uveal pigment in the injured eye acts as an allergen that causes uveitis in the other eye. Dalen-Fuchs nodules (proliferation of pigment epithelium), exudative retinal detachment, and optic disc swelling can be seen on fundoscopy. A sunset glow appearance can persist due to residual chorioretinal scarring.

Dalen-Fuchs nodules are depicted in the image below.

The exciting eye shows features of low-grade uveitis such as ciliary congestion, lacrimation, and tenderness. The sympathizing eye is usually involved 4-8 weeks later. It has a prodromal stage with photophobia, ciliary congestion, and keratic precipitates. In the fully developed stage, symptoms of acute iridocyclitis supervene.

Management options for sympathetic ophthalmitis:

  • Pulse intravenous methylprednisolone (up to 1g daily for 3 days) followed by oral prednisolone (1.5 to 2 mg per kg) is required to suppress the inflammation
  • Immunosuppressive agents such as cyclosporin, azathioprine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and chlorambucil may be used in cases non-responsive to steroids or patients who have severe side effects due to corticosteroid use
  • Enucleation of the exciting eye can be done immediately after the injury if it is not salvageable.

questions.text:
A researcher is studying 2 screening tests, A and B for a disease. He tests 100 people, half of which are cases, and obtains the following result for each of the tests. Which of the following is true regarding test B as compared to A ?
  Disease
Positive		 Disease
Negative
Test A 
positive		 46 34
Test A
negative		 04 16

 

  Disease positive Disease
Negative
Test B
positive		 36 16 

Test B

negative

  14  34
questions.solution:
In this given scenario, test B is less sensitive and more specific as compared to test A. 

Test A

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test A+

46 (TP)

34 (FP)

80

Test A-

04(FN)

16 (TN)

20

Total

50

50

100

TP - true positive; FP - false positive; TN - true negative; FN - false negative

Sensitivity = TP/(TP + FN) x 100

                = 46 / ( 46 + 4 )

Thus, sensitivity is 92% 

Specificity = TN/(FP + TN) x 100

                = 16 / ( 34 + 16 )

Thus, specificity is 32%.

Test B

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test B+

36 (TP)

16 (FP)

52

Test B-

14(FN)

34 (TN)

48

Total

50

50

100

Sensitivity = TP/(TP + FN) x 100.

                = 36 / ( 36 + 14) x 100

Thus, sensitivity is 72%.

Specificity = TN/(FP + TN) x 100.

                = 34 / ( 16 + 34 ) x 100

Thus, specificity is 68%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching. Per speculum examination of the vagina is done as shown below. A wet smear with 10% KOH solution shows budding yeast cells. The clinician prescribes an oral medication. What is the likely mechanism of action of the given medication?

choices.text: Forms pores in the fungal cell wall

questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms of curdy white vaginal discharge and the KOH smear showing budding yeast cells are suggestive of vulvovaginal candidiasis. The oral medication given in this condition is fluconazole which acts by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.

Azole group of antifungal are grouped into two types :

  • Imidazole- clotrimazole, ketoconazole, luliconazole
  • Triazole- Itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole, and isavuconazole

The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impaired conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

Therapeutic uses of fluconazole-

  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis can be treated with fluconazole by taking 100–200 mg a day for 7–14 days. Uncomplicated vaginal candidiasis can be effectively treated with a single 150 mg dose. Treatment of candidemia in nonimmunosuppressed patients involves a loading dosage of 800 mg, followed by 400 mg daily.
  • For the first eight weeks of the consolidation phase of the therapy of cryptococcal meningitis in individuals with AIDS, fluconazole is administered.
  • Due to its excellent CSF penetration and significantly lower morbidity than intrathecal amphotericin B, fluconazole is the medication of choice for treating coccidioidal meningitis. Fluconazole is similar to itraconazole in treating various types of coccidioidomycosis.

Other options

Option A- Amphotericin B acts by forming pores in the fungal cell membrane. It has also been found that it forms aggregates that sequester ergosterol from lipid bilayers, leading to fungal cell death. It is indicated in invasive mucormycosis, fungal endophthalmitis following pars plana vitrectomy, and induction therapy in cryptococcal meningitis. 

Option B- Griseofulvin acts by inhibiting microtubule assembly, disrupting the fungal cell division. It is the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. It is also effective in treating ringworm of glabrous skin, tinea cruris, tinea corprosis, tinea pedis, and tinea of the hands and beard. 

Option C- Terbinafine acts by inhibiting epoxidation of fungal squalene that reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. It is helpful for treating nail onychomycosis in adults and tinea capitis.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with pain during defecation along with the presence of blood-streaked stools. He has had a history of constipation for 5 months. On examination, a sentinel tag is present at the anal orifice. Due to extreme pain, a digital rectal examination is avoided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This case scenario with a history of chronic constipation, and the presence of sentinel tags on examination, suggests a diagnosis of anal fissure.

An anal fissure is a longitudinal split in the anoderm of the distal anal canal. A chronic anal fissure is frequently associated with:

  • Sentinel tag externally
  • Hypertrophied anal papillae internally
  • Anal ulcer overlying the internal sphincter

Anal fissures are usually seen in the young but they can occur at any age with equal sex predilection. Severe pain associated with defecation resolves spontaneously and reappears during the next evacuation. It may even be associated with the passage of fresh blood. 

Most of the fissures are located in the posterior midline followed by the anterior midline. Fissures located anywhere around the anal circumference can be possible due to other diseases like HIV, tuberculosis, syphilis, Crohn's disease, or carcinoma.

Treatment of anal fissure:

  • The focus is to normalize bowel habits. Bowel softeners, dietary fibers, and adequate water should be recommended.
  • Medical therapy involves the topical application of glyceryl trinitrate. It releases nitric oxide and relaxes the internal anal sphincter. This reduces spasms, and pain and improves vasculature to promote healing.
  • Surgical therapy is recommended for chronic fissures that have failed medical therapy. Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice where a portion of the internal sphincter is divided away from the fissure. 

Other options:

Option A: Anal fistula is usually associated with pain and intermittent purulent discharge. On examination, an external opening in the perineum can be found which opens internally in the anal canal.

Option C: Internal hemorrhoids are located proximal to the dentate line. They present with painless bleeding which is separate from the stool, and with a mass near the anal orifice. Pain is not a common feature and is present if hemorrhoids are prolapsed. 

Option D: External hemorrhoids are distal to the dentate line; these may engorge, causing pain. Pain is present throughout the day and is not only associated with defecation or rectal examination. Thrombosis of these external hemorrhoids causes severe pain. 

Related Pearl: Differences between internal and external hemorrhoids

Internal hemorrhoids External hemorrhoids
Located proximal to the dentate line

Located distal to the dentate line
Covered by transitional and columnar epithelium Covered by richly innervated squamous epithelium
Caused by pressure on superior rectal veins Caused by pressure on inferior rectal veins
Painless, can be ligated Painful, not ligated
Banding is preferred Excision is done
